Award.AwardTitle: Virtual Laboratory and Curriculum Development for Secure Mobile Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Virtual Laboratory and Curriculum Development for Secure Mobile Computing" project at the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) will develop a set of courses and a virtual laboratory in mobile system security with an emphasis on securing smart phones. The courses that will be developed will include topics such as Android taint analysis using existing tools or development of new tools, scalable Android security threat analysis on applications (apps), and smart phone forensics. To support the courses a virtual laboratory will be developed that will allow students to experiment with secure mobile computing. The laboratory will be available via a web-based interface will allow users, from around the country, to access the resource on a 24/7 basis. Students that participate in the courses and the associated virtual laboratory will be in a position to address and mitigate security concerns in in sensitive domains such as banking, military operations, healthcare, and law enforcement, where there is a rising danger associated with malware targeted at mobile devices.

This project will provide opportunities for students to carry out coursework with extensive laboratory exercises and to participate in programming competitions in smart phone security. Project evaluation will be overseen by two external evaluators. Evaluation will be based on feedback obtained from students and users of the virtual laboratory. Students will be surveyed while they are in school, at graduation, and on a monthly basis the year after they have graduated. This will allow the evaluation team to determine the efficacy of the tools that will be developed as a result of this project. Results of this work will be published in journals and at conferences such as ACM TISSEC, IEEE TDSC, IEEE S&P, ACM CCS, NDSS and USENIX Security. The virtual laboratory will be incorporated in security competitions that will help to further spread the adoption of this work beyond that of the host institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Virtual Laboratory and Curriculum Development for Secure Mobile Computing" project provides opportunities for students to carry out coursework with extensive laboratory exercises and to participate in programming competitions in smart phone security. Under this project at The University of Texas at Dallas (UTD), we developed a set of laboratory exercises in mobile system security with an emphasis on securing smart phones. The exercises that we developed include topics such as scalable Android security threat analysis on applications (apps), and smart phone forensics. In addition, we have developed a virtual laboratory that will allow students to experiment with secure mobile computing. The laboratory is available via a web-based interface and users will be able to access resources 24/7. Using this web tool, students achieve two objectives: smart phone Dynamic Analysis and Data Analytics. In dynamic analysis, students learn how to generate data. In this process, each app is installed in a controlled environment (an Android emulator) where the behavior of the app can be extracted at the network level. The data collected is encrypted and the goal is to predict the name of the app from the encrypted packets. In data analytics part, students use these data and apply a myriad of machine learning techniques to classify the apps. The interface implements various methods of feature extraction, generating a feature set that is then used in data mining algorithms in a variety of ways, depending on the data desired by the user. Once the analysis is performed, a complete report is generated at the end for the user/learner to view. Furthermore, a survey was conducted by the Big Data Management and Analytics Lab team from UTD to evaluate this web application tool. The objective of this survey was to assess the performance, significance, and other aspects of the website among users.

 

Previously, students used to perform the experiments with synthetic datasets due to the lack of real-world datasets. In this project, we collected a real-world dataset, which can be used for future research and experiments. Moreover, the designed coursework identifies recent obstacles in the field of mobile system security and data analytics, which gives students the opportunity to enhance their knowledge of these topics by working with real-world datasets and practical implementations. Students participating in the proposed laboratory exercises will also develop substantial insight on these fields, which will help them to kickstart their professional career in some of the noteworthy organizations in the industry.

 

Working with these laboratory exercises and encrypted data, we developed a novel feature extraction technique, called BIND, for fingerprinting encrypted traffic to identify an app or a website that a user is exploiting. We consider relationships among sequences of encrypted traffic packets in opposite directions. Furthermore, we explored the temporal nature of encrypted traffic and introduced an adaptive machine learning model that considers changes in behavioral patterns over time. We evaluated the proposed methods over two applications, namely website fingerprinting and app fingerprinting in both closed-world and open-world settings. In addition, we proposed a defense mechanism, called BIMORPHING, to counteract the website fingerprinting attacks. The proposed defense obfuscates original website traffic patterns through the use of double sampling and mathematical optimization techniques to deform packet sequences and destroy the traffic flow dependency characteristics used by attackers to identify websites.
